abstract.p: A passive vibration isolator with broad frequency field (zero dynamic stiffness system) is designed in this paper, whose mathematics model is built applying a mathematics method. Then the static and dynamic analysis of the isolator is conducted with ADAMS software. The zero dynamic system is developed based on theoretic study and simulation analysis. Moreover, the experimental validation of modal and frequency field is acquired. The modal experiment shows that the natural frequency of the isolator has dropped from 11.715 Hz to 2.5421 Hz because of importing negative stiffness mechanism. The result of the frequency field experiment is that the isolator has a better vibration reduction effect between 3 and 100 Hz.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Following advancements in LSI IC, ultra-precision machining and measurement technology, widespread interest has emerged concerning the influences upon machining and measuring accuracy in the said fields, by vibrations with frequencies less than 10 Hz and micro scale amplitude (Guan, 2001; He et al., 2003; Hu et al., 2003). However, common vibration isolation systems perform well only while the frequencies of the vibration remain within the range of 10–100 Hz, and are relatively ineffective when dealing with frequencies below 10 Hz. Examples include the Pisa seismic noise super attenuator (Fabbro et al., 1988; Braccini et al., 1996), seismic vibration mechanical filters for the gravitational waves detector (Giaime et al., 1996) VIRGO and passive vibration isolation stack for LIGO (Ju and Blair, 1994).

The passive vibration isolation method processes the advantages of being structurally simple, inexpensive, reliable and highly adaptable, consequently passive vibration isolation theory has experienced continuous refinements over the past, evolving from linear vibration isolation to nonlinear vibration isolation resulting in widening vibration isolation frequency bands and subsequently improved vibration isolation effects (Fujita et al., 1992; Kanda et al., 1994; Winterflood and Blair, 1996; Winterflood et al., 2002). At the present, ultra low frequency vibration isolation has already achieved significant progress including the emergence of a folded pendulum (Liu et al., 1994, 1997), crossed wire pendulum (Barton and Kuroda, 1994; Kanda et al., 1994),conical pendulum (Winterflood and Blair, 1996) whose maximum period of resonance measures up to a few dozen seconds.However progress in the development of an ultra low frequency vertical vibration isolation system has been comparably slow, largely because vibration isolation systems processing exceedingly low natural frequency demand extremely small rigidity in the loading springs, whose elastic force is required in the vertical vibration isolation system to counteract the effects of gravity. Thus, the loading spring processes a prodigious distortion space which, on one hand, would result in stability problems in the system. However on the other hand, the quality of elastic element is proportional to the energy stored within the elastic element. This energy comprises the static potential energy stored in the spring by compression from conteractions to the gravitional forces of mass block and dynamic energy from the movement (Winterflood et al., 2002). As the static deformation space enlarges, the ratio of the quality of isolated object vibration to the quality of loading spring decreases, leading to standing wave effects, namely a high frequency resonance effect which reduces the vibrating isolation bandwidth of the system (Ding, 1988). The University of Western Australia, adopted the Euler elastic element to realize low-frequency passive vibration isolation (Chin et al., 2005), its, albeit complex, structure is capable of realizing low-frequency vertical isolation, but it is ineffective in wide frequency band vibration isolation.The area of negative stiffness research witnessed continuous advances in stiffness structure implementation methods, including the emergence of magnetic suspension negative stiffness structures (Takeshi et al., 2006), steel frame negative stiffness structures (Moshrefi-Torbati et al., 2003) and square negative stiffness structures (Estrin et al., 2004) among others. These structures are however confined in their applications due to their reliance upon complex systems.A broad frequency field (zero dynamic stiffness system) based on nonlinear passive vibration damping theory and negative stiffness structure is designed in this paper to meet specifically the demand of low-frequency vibration isolation in a nanoscale two-dimensional positioning system. Building on traditional passive vibration damping theory, the new system adopts the application of a pitman spring system pocessing negative stiffness characters. As demonstrated by simulation and experiment results, the said system, appropriate for applications in vibration damping of precision instruments, possesses quailities such as a wide vibration damping frequency domain, good regulation in inherent characteristics, a good performance in environmental adaptation, a simple structure and facilitated application.

sec.title: 2. Mathematical model
sec.p: The preferred method in realizing low-frequency passive vibration isolation is to reduce the natural frequency of the vibration isolation system.
There are two options available in decreasing the natural frequency of a vibration isolation system; that is, to decrease systemic stiffness and to increase the quality of the sustained object.

In practice neither of the two methods could decrease the natural frequency to a low enough value. Thus a passive vibration isolator based on nonlinear passive vibration damping theory with a broad frequency field (zero dynamic stiffness system) is designed in this paper.
The system makes use of zero dynamic stiffness theory to reduce systematic natural frequency and realize low-frequency vibration isolation.

Zero dynamic stiffness theory reduces systematic dynamic stiffness through the parallel connection of positive and negative stiffness and the static stiffness remains constant. This method both reduces systematic natural frequency and ensures the static stability of the system.

Applied forces in the wide frequency domain passive vibration isolation system presented in this paper comprises potential energy force generated in the negative stiffness structure itself, stamina of the supporting spring and gravity of the supported object as shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Zero dynamic stiffness system schematic.
The main concern lies with the relationship of stresses and vertical displacement when the system is in equilibrium, ignoring the displacement caused by the gravity of supported object.

Hypotheses: L(mm) is the pitman length; K1(N/mm) is the stiffness of supporting spring; Ks(N/mm) is the stiffness of the vibration isolation system; K2(N/mm) is the stiffness of compressed spring; ΔL is the amount of reduction of the compressed spring; X(mm) is the dynamic displacement of balance point O.

To simplify the calculation, non-dimensional parameters α and γ are introduced, and equilibrant function F0 and negative stiffness function K0 are: F0=FK1L=2Kα(1-α-1-γ2)1-γ2γ+γ
K0=KK1=2Kα(1-α(1-γ2)3/2-1)+1
Where length parameter α = ΔL/L; displacement parameter γ = X/L; stiffness parameter Kα = K2/K1
From the two formula above it can be concluded that the dynamic stiffness of the system is required to be zero, i.e. 2Kαα = 1 when γ = 0.

Figures 2 and 3 show the relation between the displacement of dimensionless force and displacement of dimensionless stiffness when α equals to 0.01, 0.4, 0.8, 1.0. Figure 2.
Relationship between dimensionless force F0 and displacement parameters γ.
Figure 3.
Relationship between dimensionless stiffness K0 and displacement parameter γ.
As shown in Figure 3, when α = 1 i.e. when the stiffness of the supporting spring is equal to twice that of the compressed spring, the dynamic stiffness of the system is always zero.

The study of a zero dynamic stiffness system aims to realize low-frequency vibration isolation by reducing the natural frequency of the system, through adjustments of stiffness value of a compressed spring.

sec.title: 3. Simulation and analysis
sec.p:
Geometrical model of the zero dynamic stiffness system shown in Figure 4, is imported into ADAMS environment, where by exerting a certain constraint and sinusoidal stimulation with different amplitudes and frequencies, the mechanical behaviors are studied. Figure 4.
Zero dynamic stiffness system.
View, Solver, Vibration and MECHANISM/Pro modules within ADAMS are ultilized to analyze statics and kinetic characteristics of the system.

Comparisions are made specifically in regards to the dynamic responses of mass-spring system and zero dynamic stiffness passive vibration isolation system composed of supporting springs of identical mass.

Simulation parameters are as follows: the mass of the supported object is given as M = 100 kg; supporting spring is given as K1 = 13.546 N/mm, compressed spring is given as K2 = 6.860 N/mm; pitman length is given as L = 70 mm; amount of spring reduction is given as ΔL = 60 mm; the position of static equilibrium point is set to −648.6013 mm; simulating precision is 1E−4.
ADAMS simulation results match the values caculated with dislocation theory, as shown in the error row in Table 1.
That also demonstrated dynamic stiffness of the zero dynamic stiffness system processes nonlinear behavior.

Dynamic stiffness approaches zero when the amplitude is very small. The stiffness value display trends for increasing along with increasing amplitude increases; where significant increases in stiffness value have occurred when the amplitude exceeds a certain value.
Therefore, restricting the amplitude at the balance point will limit the variation ranges in dynamic stiffness value and in turn minimize the dynamic stiffness value itself.

The exact solution of a forced vibration's response is difficult to produce, due to the zero dynamic stiffness system being a nonlinear system. ADAMS software is used in time domain simulation and analysis in this paper. Figure 5 shows the dynamic response to sinusoidal stimulation whose amplitude is 0.5 mm, while the dynamic response to sinusoidal stimulation whose amplitude is 10 mm is shown in Figure 6. Figure 5.
Dynamic response to 0.5 mm amplitude sinusoidal stimulation.
Figure 6.
Dynamic response to 10 mm amplitude sinusoidal stimulation.
Figures 5(a) and 6(a) show respectively dynamic response of mass-spring system when the amplitude is equal to 0.5 mm and 10 mm;
Figures 5(b) and 6(b) shows respectively dynamic response of zero dynamic stiffness passive vibration isolation system when the amplitude is equal to 0.5 mm and 10 mm.

Comparing Figures 5(a) and (b), it is known that the response value of mass-spring system is equal to 3.5 mm and the response value of zero dynamic stiffness passive vibration isolation system is equal to 0.05 mm with the stimulation of x(t) = 0.5 sin(10t);

Comparing Figures 6(a) and (b), the response value of mass-spring system is equal to 70 mm and the response value of zero dynamic stiffness passive vibration isolation system is equal to 2.5 mm with the stimulation of x(t) = 10 sin (10t).

The result of theoretical analysis shows that when a mass-spring system is in resonance state, by adjusting the stiffness of the compressed spring response, the amplitude of a zero dynamic stiffness passive vibration isolation system and vibration transmissibillty have been reduced significantly, meaning that the natural frequency of the system underwent changes in the simulation.
Thus the vibration isolation system’s requirement regarding natural frequency could be satisfied by adjusting the parameter of zero dynamic stiffness system. Experiment is in a high frequency domain.

Since the lowest frequency of the JZK − 1 vibration exciter used in this experiment is 20 Hz, 20, 50 and 100 Hz were chosen as the fundamental frequency of the sinusoidal stimulation. Experiment schematic diagram of zero dynamic stiffness system is shown in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Schematic diagram of zero dynamic stiffness experimental system.

Figures 8 and 9 show the experimental result of vibration isolation by zero dynamic stiffness system in a high frequency band (20–100); in Figure 8 is the original stimulating signal and in Figure 9 is the response after vibration isolation. Figure 8.
Original stimulating signal.
Figure 9.
Response to original stimulating signal.

The abscissa represents frequency ranging from 0 to 400 Hz; the ordinate represents relative amplitude with unit mm. Compared with the original stimulating signal’s amplitude and the vibration isolated response signal’s amplitude, it can be concluded that the effect of vibration isolation is satisfying in the frequency band from 20 to 100 Hz.

Figure 10 shows the response to a random stimulating signal which also displays the approved vibration isolation effect. Figure 10.
Random stimulation and response.

sec.title: 4. Vibration isolation experiment in low-frequency domain
4.1. Experimental system
sec.p: Regarding the mass-spring system, the systematic natural frequency remains constant, once the spring and load’s weight is ascertained.
To the zero dynamic stiffness system, the natural frequency could be changed by adjusting the amount of reduction of the compressed spring (i.e. adjusting stiffness).
In this experiment, JZQ − 2 permanent magnetism vibration exciter is adopted to supply a square wave pumping signal, the frequency scope is limited to 3 100 Hz.
The square wave pumping signal is chosen as square signals are comprised of copious frequency elements and are capable of causing an energy change in the entire frequency spectrum.

The experimental platform consists of B & K signal analyzer unit type 2035 spectrum analyzer (frequency band is 2 ∼ 50 kHz), INV306U - 5264 data collector, YE5872 power amplifier, JZT - 2 permanent magnetism vibration exciter and CAYD140 piezoelectric acceleration transducer (sensitivity is 10 mV/ms−2, frequency band is 1–5 kHz, limit acceleration is 50 g).

Zero dynamic stiffness system experimental platform is as showed in Figure 11. Figure 11.
Zero dynamic stiffness system experimental platform.

The permanent magnetism vibration exciter with exciting frequency scope of 0 ∼ 500 Hz, peak amplitude of ±5 mm and exciting force of 10 N is installed as shown in Figure 12. Figure 12.
Installation of permanent magnet exciter.
The distortion factor is 3% when the exciting frequency is less than 0.5 Hz.

sec.title: 4.2. Modal experiment
sec.p:
Basal shock excitation is produced by a hammer blow, while a mass-spring system and zero dynamic stiffness system’s frequency responses are detected and measured with a frequency spectrograph as shown in Figures 13 and 14. Figure 13.
Mass-spring system’s frequency responses.
Figure 14.
Zero dynamic stiffness system’s frequency responses.

Due to the existence of background noises, the system’s modal response is relatively inconspicuous and the stimulating signals feeble. The systematic response value is significant only when the system is at the resonant frequency. The systematic natural frequency’s changing state could be obtained by comparing peak values in the two figures.
In the system, the supporting spring stiffness is equal to 13.546 N while the mass of load is equal to 100 kg.
The mass-spring system’s natural frequency is 11.715 Hz and the maximum value of the spectral response is close to 10 Hz as shown in Figure 10.

After installing a compression spring, the zero dynamic stiffness system’s natural frequency is 3.2567 Hz while value detected in the experiment is 2.5421 Hz. The response value is large at frequencies between 3–5 Hz while the vibration decreases at about 10 Hz.

The experiment demonstrates that the mass-spring system’s natural frequency is high; the adoption of zero dynamic stiffness system could reduce the system’s dynamic stiffness, thus obtaining lower natural frequency, which in turn extends the vibration isolation scope to below 10 Hz.

sec.title: 4.3. Frequency domain optimization experiment
sec.p:
In the frequency domain optimization experiment the supporting spring’s stiffness remains constant at 13.546 N/mm. Figure 15 shows the response spectrogram to 3 Hz squarewave stimulation and Figure 16 shows response to spectrogram 5 Hz square wave stimulation. Figure 15.
3 Hz frequency square-wave stimulation and response.
Figure 16.
5 Hz frequency square-wave stimulation and response.

In Figures 15(a) and 16(a) are the spectrograms of stimulation and response when the unoptimized compression spring’s stiffness is 6.9125N/mm (K1 ≈ 2K2). In Figures 15(b) and 16(b) are the spectrograms of stimulation and response when the optimized compression spring’s stiffness is 6.9125N/mm (K1 ≈ 2K2).

Comparing Figures 15(a) and 16(b) it can be concluded that an optimized zero dynamic stiffness system’s vibration isolating effect is superior to that of the unoptimized system when the frequency of squarewave stimulation is at 3 Hz. Mainly due to the nonlinear system’s subharmonic resonance, unoptimized systems produced unsatisfactory vibration isolating effects within 10 20 Hz frequency domain, although the system performed better within the 3 ∼ 10 Hz frequency domain. After optimizing the system’s damping capacity enhanced greatly.
As shown in Figure 15(b), the original stimulation’s amplitude differs from that of the optimized system by nearly an order of magnitude.

Especially within the 3 ∼ 10 Hz frequency domain, the vibration isolation’s effects are apparent with stability maintained in the vibration isolated system while the vibration of subharmonic resonance weakens.

The results of the experiment demonstrates: stimulated by 3 Hz squarewave the vibration isolating effect was much better when the compression spring’s stiffness was 6.9125 N/mm than when it was 13.546 N/mm and the conclusion that the system was optimized within 3 ∼ 100 Hz frequency domain was tenable.
According to Figure 16, within 3 ∼ 100 Hz frequency domain, the original pumping signal’s amplitude was 0.01 ∼ 1 mm and the zero dynamic stiffness system’s amplitude was 0.001 mm ∼ 0.1 mm.

After optimization the system’s vibration isolating effect matched the simulation rersults.Meanwhile that illustrated zero dynamic stiffness system stimulated by 5 Hz squarewave presented a vibration isolating effect within 3 ∼ 100 Hz frequency domain.

list-item.p: The conclusion of theoretical calculation and simulation analysis demonstrates that when the supporting spring’s stiffness is equal to twice that of the compressed spring’s, the system’s theoretical natural frequency is zero. In this case, the damping effect is optimal.
According to the high-frequency domain experiment, in the 20–100 Hz frequency band, the damping effect is good.
According to the modal experiment, zero dynamic stiffness system could reduce the system’s dynamic stiffness and in turn obtains a lower natural frequency.

According to the frequency-domain optimization experiment, the stiffness of the zero dynamics system introduced in this paper has a good damping effect in the 3 ∼ 100 Hz frequency domain. At the same time, optimized zero dynamic stiffness system’s damping effects is better than unoptimized system in 3 ∼ 10 Hz frequency domain.
The zero dynamic stiffness system presented in this paper has broadened the frequency range and has a good damping effect.
